title: MLB GPP Pivots: Sunday 9/1
text:
Welcome to the MLB GPP Pivots article, where we’ll be looking to uncover some sneaky-good DFS plays away from the popular lifts. These recommendations are usually risk/reward commodities meant to be used in large-field tournaments. Typically, blending these low-owned hidden gems with well-aligned staples contributes to a viable GPP strategy.

Keep in mind that the following player write-ups were constructed earlier in the day, and sometimes injury/rest situations can alter the fantasy landscape. Monitoring our MLB News & Headlines Feed throughout the day will keep you in the loop while giving you the subsequent DFS consequences of each information piece.

We will be looking at the eight-game main slate beginning at 1:05 ET.

Scroll to continue with content Ad

PITCHER

Miles Mikolas - St. Louis (vs. Cincinnati)

Mikolas struggled through the majority of August, allowing five earned runs across three straight starts. However, he bounced back nicely last Tuesday, racking up ten strikeouts while yielding only four hits and one earned run at Milwaukee. He’ll look to carry that momentum into today’s home draw against Cincinnati, who ranks 22nd in wRC+ this season. On top of that, Mikolas’ salary has fallen considerably due to those recent struggles, so this is an interesting buy-low opportunity.

CATCHER / FIRST BASE

Ryan O’Hearn - Kansas City (vs. Baltimore)

Story continues

O’Hearn was considered a sleeper for season-long fantasy baseball at the beginning of the season, but things haven’t exactly gone his way while holding a .184 average with 10 homers through 272 at-bats. However, that doesn’t mean we should ignore him for daily fantasy purposes, especially considering his recent tear of eight hits and three homers over his past six games. The matchup looks promising against Baltimore RHP Aaron Brooks (.359 wOBA vs. LHB) and a generous Orioles’ bullpen.

SECOND BASE

Brian Dozier - Washington (vs. Miami)

Speaking of disappointing seasons, Brian Dozier’s 2019 campaign probably falls into that category. He hasn’t done much for fantasy backers recently either, as a snapshot of his game log looks pretty bleak. However, we all know that Dozier is a capable bat against left-handed pitching, and he’ll step into a sneaky-good matchup against Miami LHP Caleb Smith. The Marlins’ southpaw looked great to begin the season, but he has fallen on tough times while allowing five or more earned runs in three of his past five starts.

THIRD BASE

Hunter Dozier - Kansas City (vs. Baltimore)

Let’s turn our attention to Hunter Dozier, who is no relation to Brian (I double-checked). The Kansas City third baseman is enjoying a breakout season while hitting .278 with 24 homers and 75 RBIs. As mentioned earlier, Baltimore RHP Aaron Brooks has been kind to opposing hitters, currently sporting a .351 wOBA split to right-handed bats. Dozier has slapped a pair of homers over his last four starts, and he could keep that momentum in this friendly draw.

SHORTSTOP

Paul DeJong - St. Louis (vs. Cincinnati)

We can’t forget about the Cardinals this afternoon, who will square off against Cincinnati spot-starter Tyler Mahle. Even though Mahle has gotten shelled by left-handed bats throughout his career (.397 wOBA split), I’m not counting out right-handed hitters like Paul Goldschmidt and Paul DeJong. The latter has been warming up over the past week or two, and there’s not a ton of opportunity cost at the shortstop position this afternoon.

OUTFIELD

Khris Davis - Oakland (at NY Yankees)

Davis has a questionable tag next to his name, but he’s expected to return from the paternity list to start today’s game. He’ll settle into a pretty good matchup as well, facing volatile NYY lefty J.A. Happ with a park boost at Yankee Stadium. This is a strong leverage opportunity if Davis cracks the lineup - as expected.

Jake Cave - Minnesota (at Detroit)

Byron Buxton is still hurt, and Marwin Gonzalez is dealing with an injury as well. The Twins called up outfielder LaMonte Wade, but I’m expecting Jake Cave to start in right field today. He would make for an adequate fantasy bargain if that’s the case, facing Detroit RHP Spencer Turnbull’s .350 wOBA split to left-handed bats. Cave has been a pleasant surprise lately, recording a pair of multi-homer performances over the past week.
